attributes.value: / For most cases, you can simply use the [`decode`], [`encode`] and
/ [`encode_upper`] functions. If you need a bit more control, use the traits

defs.name: InvalidHexCharacter
defs.docs:
An invalid character was found. Valid ones are: `0...9`, `a...f`
 or `A...F`.

attributes.value: / An invalid character was found. Valid ones are: `0...9`, `a...f`

defs.name: OddLength
defs.docs:
A hex string's length needs to be even, as two digits correspond to
 one byte.

defs.name: InvalidStringLength
defs.docs:
If the hex string is decoded into a fixed sized container, such as an
 array, the hex string's length * 2 has to match the container's
 length.

defs.name: FromHexError
defs.docs: The error type for decoding a hex string into `Vec<u8>` or `[u8; N]`.

attributes.value: / The error type for decoding a hex string into `Vec<u8>` or `[u8; N]`.
/ This trait is implemented for all `T` which implement `AsRef<[u8]>`. This

defs.name: encode_hex
defs.docs:
Encode the hex strict representing `self` into the result. Lower case
 letters are used (e.g. `f9b4ca`)

 letters are used (e.g. `F9B4CA`)

defs.name: FromHex
defs.docs: Types that can be decoded from a hex string.

attributes.value: / Types that can be decoded from a hex string.
/ This trait is implemented for `Vec<u8>` and small `u8`-arrays.

defs.name: from_hex
defs.value: pub fn from_hex<T: AsRef<[u8]>>(T) -> Result<Self, Self::Error>
defs.docs:
Creates an instance of type `Self` from the given hex string, or fails
 with a custom error type.

attributes.value: / Creates an instance of type `Self` from the given hex string, or fails
/ Both, upper and lower case characters are valid and can even be
/ mixed (e.g. `f9b4ca`, `F9B4CA` and `f9B4Ca` are all valid strings).

defs.name: encode
defs.docs: Encodes `data` as hex string using lowercase characters.

attributes.value: / Encodes `data` as hex string using lowercase characters.
/ Lowercase characters are used (e.g. `f9b4ca`). The resulting string's
/ length is always even, each byte in `data` is always encoded using two hex
/ digits. Thus, the resulting string contains exactly twice as many bytes as

defs.name: encode_upper
defs.docs: Encodes `data` as hex string using uppercase characters.

attributes.value: / Encodes `data` as hex string using uppercase characters.
/ Apart from the characters' casing, this works exactly like `encode()`.

defs.name: decode
defs.value: pub fn decode<T: AsRef<[u8]>>(T) -> Result<Vec<u8>, FromHexError>
defs.docs: Decodes a hex string into raw bytes.

attributes.value: / Decodes a hex string into raw bytes.
/ Both, upper and lower case characters are valid in the input string and can
/ even be mixed (e.g. `f9b4ca`, `F9B4CA` and `f9B4Ca` are all valid strings).

defs.name: encode_to_slice
defs.value:
pub fn encode_to_slice<T: AsRef<[u8]>>(T, &mut [u8])

defs.docs: Encodes some bytes into a mutable slice of bytes.

attributes.value: / Encodes some bytes into a mutable slice of bytes.
/ The output buffer, has to be able to hold at least `input.len() * 2` bytes,
/ otherwise this function will return an error.
